channel.title: Spring JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [BATCH-1916] RecordSeparatorPolicy#isEndOfRecord wrong javadoc?
item.description:
I have an issue using FlatFileItemReader with a custom RecordSeparatorPolicy. The javadoc of RecordSeparatorPolicy#isEndOfRecord tells

Signal the end of a record based on the content of a line, being the latest line read from an input source. The input is what you would expect from BufferedReader.readLine() - i.e. no line separator character at the end. But it might have line separators embedded in it.

I would think the parameter is last read line from file. If I see the code of
FlatFileItemReader#applyRecordSeparatorPolicy

 
while (line != null && !recordSeparatorPolicy.isEndOfRecord(record)) {

Actually this is not a line, this is whole record. It makes FlatFileItemReader unusable for my purposes.

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
This is just a line. If you follow the flow:

  • doRead() calls readLine() at line 172.
  • readLine() calls this.reader.readLine() at line 200 which is nothing more than readLine on an instance of a BufferedReader.
  • applyRecordSeparatorPolicy is called with the result of the readLine method in the previous step.

The documentation is correct. It says record in the line of code you pasted due to the fact that the line variable passed as an argument is assigned to a new variable called record as shown below:

	private String applyRecordSeparatorPolicy(String line) throws IOException {
 
 
 
		String record = line;
 
		while (line != null && !recordSeparatorPolicy.isEndOfRecord(record)) {
 
 

What is the behavior you were expecting?

I would expect 

while (line != null && !recordSeparatorPolicy.isEndOfRecord(line)) {

how it goes from javadoc of RecordSeparatorPolicy#isEndOfRecord.

Signal the end of a record based on the content of a line, being the latest line read from an input source.

There is clearly about line not record.
Sorry, the subject is little bit provocative. I believe the javadoc of RecordSeparatorPolicy is correct and we have an issue with FlatFileItemReader.
Do you have a test case that reproduces the behavior you are having issues with that you can post?

Imagine that we have a file with such structure

start:cat
 
<some data>
 
..
 
end:cat
 
 
 
start:dog
 
<some data>
 
..
 
end:dog
 
 
 
<and so on>

The record is the block starting with start and ending with end. If a line is passed to isEndOfRecord method there is the clean way to recognize the end of record. Otherwise there is not. Could you follow me?

From what you are describing, that is a multiline record. For that, we have in the documentation how to handle it it using multiple LineTokenizers. You can read more about it in section 11.5 here: http://static.springsource.org/spring-batch/reference/html/patterns.html

I don't think It suits. I don't need tokenizing at all! What all I need is to separate the records. RecordSeparatorPolicy of FlatFileItemReader would be the best solution if IMHO there is no the bug in FlatFileItemReader.

Based on the sample data above, for delimiting lines, why would the following not work?

package org.springsource.batch.reader;
 
 
 
import java.util.regex.Matcher;
 
import java.util.regex.Pattern;
 
 
 
import org.springframework.batch.item.file.separator.RecordSeparatorPolicy;
 
 
 
public class CustomerEndOfRecordPolicy implements RecordSeparatorPolicy {
 
 
 
	private Pattern pattern = Pattern.compile("end:.*$");
 
 
 
	public boolean isEndOfRecord(String line) {
 
		boolean endOfRecord = false;
 
 
 
		Matcher matcher = pattern.matcher(line);
 
 
 
		if(matcher.find()) {
 
			endOfRecord = true;
 
		}
 
 
 
		return endOfRecord;
 
	}
 
 
 
	public String postProcess(String record) {
 
		return record;
 
	}
 
 
 
	public String preProcess(String record) {
 
		return record;
 
	}
 
 
 
}

I tested it against the following data successfully:

start:customer
 
Ross
 
1-340-528-9325
 
sit@Aliquam.co.uk
 
Ap #348-1484 Ante Road
 
Bellevaux-Ligneuville
 
end:customer
 
start:customer
 
Kermit
 
1-702-837-0140
 
nunc.sed.libero@mauris.co.uk
 
P.O. Box 138, 130 Phasellus Rd.
 
Des Moines
 
end:customer
 
start:customer
 
Hadassah
 
1-590-190-5665
 
montes.nascetur@necenimNunc.org
 
4243 Magna. Rd.
 
Southwell
 
end:customer
 
start:customer
 
Francis
 
1-567-301-7810
 
Curabitur.egestas.nunc@nunc.co.uk
 
8762 Interdum Rd.
 
Phoenix
 
end:customer

For sure it works. I didn't mind that is impossible to implement such policy. I mind there is no clean way to do it because we lose information about where the line starts. So it looks like a workaround. I can imagine an example where your solution does not work. For instance

start:customer
 
some information end: some information
 
end:customer

It is quite artificial but an example.

If it is rather impossible to fix the issue in FlatFileItemReader, it would be nice when javadoc of isEndOfRecord reflects clearly the fact that the parameter is not the current line that was read from file but some buffer for record that waits for completion.
Probably it could possible to extend RecordSeparatorPolicy with a possibility to access the line there to be able make decision about end of record.

Thanks for your effort.

While I will agree that the javadoc is misleading in that it implies that the method does get the line (when compared to the other methods in the RecordSeparatorPolicy) and we can update that. However, I don't think the actual behavior should change. The interface offers the preProcess method to allow you to manipulate the record prior to appending the next read line. By doing so, you can still get the effect of receiving individual lines or the entire record in the isEndOfRecord method. For example, you could use the preProcess method to append a newline character at the end of the record then split on that character in the isEndOfRecord method. The last element of the split string would be the line last read.

With regards to the example you posted above, my implementation was based on the previous data set you provided that had records ending with different values (end:cat and end:dog). If end:customer is the consistent end of a record, then you should be able to just update the regular expression, correct?
I agree with you. The issue can be closed after javadoc is corrected.
